descendants.content:
And beyond just shitting on Koch, not that it isn't a worthy cause by itself, this is exactly why carbon offsets work much better in theory than in practice.

We should not be incentivizing the cultivation of water-intensive Alfalfa in arid regions, especially when doing so takes away from local impoverished populations.

This is not the way to fight climate change, nor make progress towards any sustainability goals.

descendants.content:
@FantasticalEconomics

This is the same shit that went down in Syria in the decade before economic collapse culminated in civil collapse.

State policy in the years leading into a 5 year drought favored the production of dates for export rather than grain for domestic consumption. Upstream water use changes compounded with prolonged drought to sink the value of the currency. Date sales could do nothing to offset the increased cost of domestic crop failures.

The currency devalued, Syria underwent economic collapse, within a year the government failed, civil war, the movement of foreign backing to prop up a government complicit in the ransacking of the nations natural resources.

account.note: Jumped the paddock afforded to me, now I'm happily grafted onto a rock in the Pacific. My roots are still in #SoFlo.

fields.name: Emerson's words, my sentiments:
fields.value: https://openlibrary.org/books/OL7042536M/Emerson%27s_essay_on_compensation

descendants.content:
@OvertonDoors

It's a too-familiar story. It's the tragic outcome of economic imperialism. The specifics change slightly based on the country, but the core of the tragedy just keeps on repeating.

And few, if any, of these repeating examples of globalization pillaging poor nations are taught in economics classes, leading many to still believe that free trade brings economic well-being to the poor. Rather, it's a system that benefits the rich and powerful (shocking, I know).

descendants.content:
@PJ_Evans

That's what it sounds like. This is the sad story of trade in poorer nations: some folks in government get a kickback, the foreign company gets to extract with impunity, and the people suffer.

Very different from the "free trade makes everyone better off" bs we still teach in economics.

@maugendre
